title: Converting document IDs to allow any primary key
body:
This refactoring introduces a new type, DocumentId, which allows any
`Key` implementing type to be used as a DocumentId, with the only
restriction being that DocumentIds are currently limited to 64 bytes in
length.

This restriction is to allow Header to remain copy, and allow it to not
require an external allocation.

Overall the impact to the code isn't that bad, but this is an initial
draft to have a discussion around the idea with other users.

Remaining tasks as of 2-17:
- [x] Consider naming consistency: Id vs PrimaryKey vs DocumentId vs DocumentKey.
- [x] Add example showing custom primary keys.
- [x] Refactor Key to a new location now that it's not view-specific.
- [x] Refactor document.rs into smaller files. Should DocumentId be moved externally so that it can be used in Actionable rules?
- [ ] Add section on PrimaryKey to book
- [x] Update changelog
- [x] Add macro unit tests

title: Work around panic in tokio::time::sleep()
body:
A user showed a stack trace of a crash that resulted from the key-value
background task attempting to sleep forever by passing a large Duration.
The example the user was running doesn't use expiration at all, so the
loop is meant to sleep forever.

I'm uncertain what is causing this to panic on their machine and not on
any of the test environments I've run on except that they're on Windows.
The tokio code as far as I can tell has no platform-specific code in
that area, so I'm baffled. I reported tokio-rs/tokio#4494.

In the meantime, I've changed the logic to support a "Never" sleep
target which avoids calling sleep() when there's no expiration target.
This makes the code a little more complicated (the reason I went with
the original approach), but it should fix the panic the user was seeing.

title: Add lz4 compression support
body:
Closes #185

This is a first pass at compression support. I believe that ultimately
we'll want to support both zstd and lz4, but right now feature flags are
really annoying to implement. When we can implement namespaced features
(#178), we should revisit adding multiple compression backends and
options. lz4-flex has a faster unsafe option that can be enabled
optionally, but I've kept disabled in the spirit of BonsaiDb's "safe"
defaults.

From my research, zstd will be preferred when storage is at a premium,
but lz4 *should* be faster in general. I want to write a good benchmark
suite, because I believe the relative performance will potentially be
hardware dependent, and users should be able to gauge what works best
for them.

title: Derive: collection(encryption), view(serialization), schema

title: Reduce copying by borrowing during view mapping
body:
This refactor is focused around allowing the view mapping system to avoid extra clones of bytes under the hood. I had originally gone as far as making the network request types also do data borrowing, but I quickly realized that the only way to get data to be able to be sent across a spawn-able task layer is to convert it to a static lifetime -- defeating the original purpose of borrowing.

After those realizations, I settled on having an OwnedDocument type and eliminating `'static` lifetimes in the API as much as I could. The CHANGELOG documents the specific changes, and overall I'm pretty happy with the state of things.

title: Support deriving Collection
body:
I also added trybuild to test the error messages of derive macro.

The macro does not check for name validity as the restrictions will be
removed https://github.com/khonsulabs/bonsaidb/issues/143#issuecomment-1019278177.

closes #138

title: Split View into View and ViewSchema
body:
This PR aims to allow defining the map/reduce implementations separately from the view implementations. Sadly, default associated types are not supported, so this means a little extra code for the simple case. But, this feels like the right move for the design of BonsaiDb as it keeps the code not needed in a Client out of the client, if you structure your code that way.

Closes #99.

- [x] Split View/ViewSchema
- [x] Update book + docs
- [x] Write changelog entry

title: Add 'realistic' commerce benchmark
body:
In an effort to provide a somewhat meaningful benchmark tool that can
simulate different situations in a transactional environment, this
benchmark aims to simulate operations performed for a commerce
application.

This is still a work in progress.

title: Switch to chunk-level encryption
body: Fixes #75.

title: Refactoring to use Nebari's transaction logs
body:
This ended up being a larger job. The current state of this branch is
that all unit tests except backup are passing. Backup needs to be
updated with how to handle the transaction log.

Most of the refactor in this change is switching from a single Roots
instance to multiple instances. This is how BonsaiDb used to be
structured with multiple instances of Sled, but I switched away from
that method to minimize the issues with multiple caches and not being
able to control the number of background processes sled was using.

Since I'm in control of Nebari, I just added the support necessary to
share thread pools and file managers. To avoid issues with Database and
Storage keeping each other alive, the Context type is used to share
Roots instances between Database instances.

- [x] ~Re-implement transaction log backup~ Bad idea -- Nebari creates a new transaction log history when importing the data. I can't think of a valid reason to keep the transaction log data in a restore situation -- the transaction log data is primarily for replication, and if you're using replication, there's no reason to do a restore from backup -- you'd swap over to the replica or restore from the replica using replication, not this backup process.
- [x] Store executed transactions directly in Nebari (needs khonsulabs/nebari#14)

title: Add User Authentication
body:
This pull request will add the ability to create and log in as a user. Passwords are exchanged using [`custodian-password`](https://github.com/khonsulabs/custodian/tree/main/password). This is a simplified wrapper around the leading `OPAQUE-PAKE` implementation. We will have simple, easy to understand documentation about this before long, but the summary is that the password for the users will be encrypted on the client before being sent to the server, and the server has no way of knowing the original password. Yet, it can be confident on a subsequent login that the password provided is the same with additional validations being able to be done on the client if state is able to be saved. tl;dr: what's better than storing salted+hashed passwords? Not storing anything valuable at all, yet still being able to verify a login securely!

Part of making this work is also needing to be able store secrets securely, so the beginnings of a Vault is also being implemented in this pull request.

Todos:
- [x] Add opaque networking types
- [x] Implement user management
- [x] Determine how to handle encryption key permissions
- [x] Fix docs that still reference server instead of storage.
- [x] Implement document encryption/decryption
- [x] Logged In event on backend
- [x] Delete User
- [x] Add test flows for being unable to retrieve a document due to missing permissions to the encryption key.
- ~[ ] Backup support -- either decrypt or need to store the key id and export the keys.~ Split to #67.
- [x] Document encryption
- ~[ ] Key Value encryption~ Split to #66.
- [x] Add `PublicKeyEncryption` enum that has the current algorithm set for HPKE. Add this to the HPKEPayload struct, allowing us to migrate to other algorithms in the future and be able to distinguish between them.
